articles.headline: Liberia’s Women Warn Male Presidential Candidates: Keep the Peace
articles.snippet: A man will almost certainly become the country’s next leader, and women are worried that their newfound gains will be lost.
articles.abstract: A man will almost certainly become the country’s next leader, and women are worried that their newfound gains will be lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — On the eve of a presidential election that will almost certainly return male rule to Liberia after 12 years, women delivered a warning.

articles.headline: China Hastens the World Toward an Electric-Car Future
articles.snippet: The biggest automakers in the world are being forced to follow Beijing’s lead as China takes steps to dominate in electric vehicles and technology.
articles.abstract: The biggest automakers in the world are being forced to follow Beijing’s lead as China takes steps to dominate in electric vehicles and technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — There is a powerful reason that automakers worldwide are speeding up their efforts to develop electric vehicles — and that reason is China.

articles.headline: How Russia Harvested American Rage to Reshape U.S. Politics
articles.snippet: A Times examination of Russian-linked Facebook pages used in the 2016 election found that much of the content was taken directly from videos and posts from Americans.
articles.abstract: A Times examination of Russian-linked Facebook pages used in the 2016 election found that much of the content was taken directly from videos and posts from Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: YouTube videos of police beatings on American streets. A widely circulated internet hoax about Muslim men in Michigan collecting welfare for multiple wives. A local news story about two veterans brutally mugged on a freezing winter night.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Kobe Steel’s Falsified Data Is Another Blow to Japan’s Reputation
articles.snippet: Employees altered inspection certificates to meet specifications, setting off a rush by Toyota, Boeing and others to see if they had used the raw materials.
articles.abstract: Employees altered inspection certificates to meet specifications, setting off a rush by Toyota, Boeing and others to see if they had used the raw materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Big manufacturers of cars, aircraft and bullet trains have long relied on Kobe Steel to provide raw materials for their products, making the steel maker a crucial, if largely invisible, pillar of the Japanese economy.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Soble and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Start-Up Bets on Tech Talent Pipeline From Africa
articles.snippet: Andela, which has attracted the attention and money of people like Mark Zuckerberg, trains and employs workers in Africa to do programming.
articles.abstract: Andela, which has attracted the attention and money of people like Mark Zuckerberg, trains and employs workers in Africa to do programming.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tolulope Komolafe first heard the pitch, she was skeptical. A fledgling company in Lagos, Nigeria, would pay her to learn how to write modern computer code and then offer her a good job in the high-tech economy.

articles.headline: Masayoshi Son’s Grand Plan for SoftBank’s $100 Billion Vision Fund
articles.snippet: Mr. Son has told tech entrepreneurs he is on a mission to own pieces of all the companies that may underpin the shifts brought on by artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: Mr. Son has told tech entrepreneurs he is on a mission to own pieces of all the companies that may underpin the shifts brought on by artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Eric Gundersen, the chief executive of a mapping start-up called Mapbox, met Masayoshi Son, the head of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, in late July, he expected to have to sell Mr. Son on what made Mapbox important.

articles.headline: Procter & Gamble Declares Victory in Proxy Battle; Peltz Says, Not So Fast
articles.snippet: The company said it defeated an attempt by the activist investor Nelson Peltz to win a seat on its board. But Mr. Peltz’s company said the vote was too close to call.
articles.abstract: The company said it defeated an attempt by the activist investor Nelson Peltz to win a seat on its board. But Mr. Peltz’s company said the vote was too close to call.
articles.lead_paragraph: The largest and most expensive corporate proxy battle in history ended with a big question mark.

articles.headline: California Fires Lay Waste to 140,000 Acres and Rage On
articles.snippet: The two biggest and most destructive fires consumed more than 52,000 acres in Napa and Sonoma Counties, the heart of wine country.
articles.abstract: The two biggest and most destructive fires consumed more than 52,000 acres in Napa and Sonoma Counties, the heart of wine country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — With roads still blocked by the police and fires still raging across broad swaths of Northern California, Matt Lenzi hiked through smoke-choked vineyards and waded the Napa River to reach the home his father lived in for 53 years. In its place, he found only blackened debris, blackened earth, and ash.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Richard Pérez-Peña and Jonah Engel Bromwich

articles.headline: Why Big Cities Thrive, and Smaller Ones Are Being Left Behind
articles.snippet: Population is a growing source of economic cleavage, as larger metropolitan areas adapt better to the disruptions arising from trade and technology.
articles.abstract: Population is a growing source of economic cleavage, as larger metropolitan areas adapt better to the disruptions arising from trade and technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t want to be hit by a recession in a city like Steubenville, Ohio.
